comments.commentBody: ...and since when does someone having 'died' become the standard to judge whether a 'game' goes bad?  I would've thought adding an extra $24 billion (for the one shutdown) to the deficit for no good reason than to pull a political stunt--and lose--would be enough to indicate that.  Again, there's no point in accusing politicians of playing politics, that's what they do.  But to act on the threat and yes, Hold The Government Hostage to legislative demands they couldn't get on the floor of the legislature...is extortion, legislative or otherwise.
If that was true they would not keep cutting taxes at every opportunity. They would close loop holes and use the revenue on jobs and debt reduction like Pres. Clinton

What Mr. Boehner did was follow the money - the national Chamber of Commerce and other big corporations were furious at the money they lost during the last debt limit boondoogle, and they wasted no time in letting their money talk - I am sure Boehner and others got the message loud and clear that threatening the US with default and the world economy with the consequences would not be tolerated ever again.
Yeah, when people who don't pay taxes vote for free stuff for themselves, it's amazing what kind of debt we can run up.

HALinNY,

re your final contrabution yesterday, 'How do you make a fluffernutter?', I suggest you hand him a lumpy pillow.

If you make a bad pun on these boards, you SHARPEI for it.

Sad that you finally make a straightforward comment, and look what I do to you.

This was really a fun puzzle. Very nice grid, big fills, some clever cluing. Not terribly difficult but with some uncommon words and not much, if any, crosswordese. Just plain fun.

Thanks to all.
Before everyone starts high fiving each other, make sure the resolution gets through the Senate without any concessions.
Nothing more than a pause between rounds.....

The world is literally crawling with people just as deserving, just as poor. We admit a million legal immigrants a year, the largest number of any country on the planet. There is no reason to be giving preferential treatment to scofflaws who waltz across the southern border.
Each state determines whether felons can vote. Some allow it, some don't. This includes voting for president and US legislators.

Mr. Holder needs to start his movement in his own house: felons cannot vote in federal elections and are subject to arrest if they try to do so. So many Americans are disenfranchised that the fact affects many elections. After prison and probation is finished, those rights should be restored, as well as gun rights for non-violent offenders. Imagine not being able to vote nor being able to defend your family in a time of civil unrest; then think of the contempt that engenders for the rule of law among those who have felt the sting of the lash.
Good for Eric Holder! It's about time!!  When someone's debt to society is paid, it's paid.  They shouldn't lose the most sacred right of all American citizens - our birthright - the vote.

Voting isn't a privilege given to those who are good in some way, it's the mechanism by which we establish a government by consent of the governed.  It should go to everyone who is subject to the law because they are subject to the law.
I can't think of any circumstances that would justify taking away a citizen's right to vote.

The US has 5% of the world's population and 25% of its incarcerated - and we lecture other countries on human rights abuses while Arizona's favorite sheriff leaves inmates in tents in 100  degree weather and feeds them peanut butter sandwiches. Other states feed inmates twice a day and some are starting to charge them for meals. It is inhumane.

For the past 40 odd years we have had a quite expensive war on crime, mostly drug related, though sadly soft on the white collar variety which alone costs many billions. U.S Inmate population went from about 550k in 1980 to 2.3 million today, the largest in the world. About 95% of prisoners will be back in society at some point. This has led to a former felon population that must be in the millions and disenfranchised from voting. Though some states even more conservative ones seem to be taking the lede. If we want these folks to be restored, productive members of society a phased in restoration of voting rights is imperative.

Interesting point: Two states, ME and Vt allow prison inmates to vote. When people there are incarcerated they are not stripped of the right to vote. When there is an election the authorities bring the voting machines to the prisons. I once read that voting patterns were more conservative than would be expected. No softees on crime those inmates.

MTF, SHEESH! You really Moustafa with these Maura Tierney Fan sign offs that conclude each and everyone of your remarks...you should seriously consider putting a D.O.A. TOETAG on all of them!

Howie TBOQ Forever!

Really, the most punative post-incarceration problem is that checkbox on every single employment application in the United States:

"Have you ever been convicted of a criminal offense"

Check that checkbox and say goodbye to ever again holding a decent job and successfully reintegrating with society. Employers shouldn't be allowed to ask this, except perhaps in certain jobs where the prior criminal history is relevant.

... there's also the fact that if you have an employment gap of longer than 6 months your chance of getting a job drops drastically.

We, as a country, do EVERYTHING we can to make things as tough as possible for felons reintegrating into society and as a result we have terrible recidivism rates. You don't get much or any help when you get out. You can't get a good job. Any little offense sends you back to prison. It's almost like we want people to go back to jail where we can flush $50k per prisoner per year of taxpayer dollars. It's just stupid, morally, logically, financially.

Disenfranchisement is not limited to voting. States, including those that permit voting for ex-felons, prohibit jury service, which is also a right and responsibility of citizenship.

Stigmatizing "felons" should not extend at all beyond their time served and probationary or parole period. Otherwise, it's a life sentence.

The disgrace here is that our veterans were the first to take a hit on their retirement.  You can characterize the past two wars in any terms you choose but to our veterans should receive what they were already promised.  Shame on those allowed COLA to be affected.

While I haven't watched a S.T. film in years, I've watched almost all of them growing up, especially in my late childhood/early teen years. She was my inspiration to learn tap. I'd always liked the golden age movies and it was so easy to lose oneself in hers. Always optimistic, looking on the bright side, a song to fight the odds with, and a positive ending with a big smile. Her Mother saw to it that she was protected & pampered but not spoiled. So protected that she had no idea of the Depression for a long time. Mother always told Shirley that her movies made people happy. Recently viewing "Since You Went Away" I will put that also into my favorites of ST films. Shirley Temple had a lucky star that shone high & bright and today is a little dimmed in the heavens by the sadness of her passing.
Lighten up .
No , Wallmart is too good . . . Shirley is to Saks as Honey Boo Boo is to the worst thrift store .

"On the good ship lollipop" will never be sung again like Shirley Temple
sang it !!

Those recommending tranquilizers should take a week off and go to the forest. You will soon realize that you don't trust anything weak against these animals, and your feelings of morality will be replaced by feelings of fear. Now if you have a really good tranquilizer gun that can be trusted like a lethal gun, by all means give it to the hunters.

How many wild carnivores have you allowed to thrive in New York that you speak with such authority? And did you even react to yesterdays news about the impending slaughter of bisons in our national parks?  So easy to judge others, no?

“Now there is no alternative except to kill her,” he said. “Otherwise she will keep on killing people. It is a very dicey game, which is very dangerous, and thrilling, as well.”

Killing an endangered breeding tiger is morally reprehensible. Surely if they can find her, they can tranquilize her and move her to an enclosed sanctuary where both she and humans would be safe. Man has killed far more wildlife than any threat from any animal. When will we ever stop our systematic execution of life on the only living planet in the cosmos?

Actually, I think it was the most truthful and facts-on-the-ground statement in the whole report.  I cannot talk for him, but what I understand from that stmt is that human beings should be more careful in Tiger reserves, and generally when they venture out into the 'wild'.

Mad.madrasi, one person was attacked in a sugarcane field, another off a public road running through a public park.

People need to be told to stay away from tigers? What does the director's sage advice mean? That people should avoid meeting tigers by accident?

“Usually, when a tiger and a human meet, it is the tiger that ends up doing most of the damage,” he said. “The human being is likely to come off worse.”

That is the director of the park speaking. People with such penetrating insight are running the show; no wonder the tiger hasn't been found.
Anecdote alert...
Although it's wonderful you're alive...there's no way to prove if a mammogram saved your life.
Indeed we should, but corporate greed rules the nation.

The respondents here clearly aren't diabetics.
Yes, improvements in diet and exercise are very, very important,
...but it is infantile to imagine that this is enough to undo the damage once it has been done.
The system is like a spring that has been stretched past its maximum....it never has the same strength it did before that event...or at least not long after a long period of adjustment.
Also...being super active isn't always easy depending on the environment you're in. Try mountain biking and jogging in Cairo here with me and you'll likely find yourself dead in no time at all.

Dudley, you seem to have misread me. To be sure, once Type II diabetes has progressed to a certain point, it can't be reversed through dietary intervention. This may be true of obesity as well. However, these conditions can almost always be prevented.

It's also worth noting that insulin resistance can be reversed, and if that happens, and the pancreas is still sufficiently functional, diabetes can indeed be reversed -- although cumulative damage to the pancreas is permanent. You might find interesting a promising small-scale study that found the paleolithic diet superior to a standard diabetes diet in controlling diabetes:

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2724493/

Finally, agree with you about Cairo, but jogging isn't the only form of exercise.

Interesting research. But we humans too are exquisitely adapted genetically to our traditional diets, which include a wide range of foods but don't include modern innovations like hydrogenated oils and refined sugar. And everywhere in the world, as modern processed foods have replaced traditional staples, people have developed the "diseases of civilization" -- obesity, heart disease, diabetes, and similar ills.

Even a bear will become ill if its fed the wrong kind of food. Rather than making ourselves sick and then looking for pharmaceutical fixes, shouldn't we remove unhealthy foods from our diet, thus avoiding obesity in the first place?
